name: dimethyl malonate production | dimethyl malonate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8528/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of dimethyl malonate.The production pathway is based on hydrogen cyanide and chloroacetic acid; the intermediate cyanoacetic acid is simultaneously saponified and esterified in the presence of a large excess of mineral acid and alcohol.;The dimethyl malonate (C5H8O4 | DMM) is a colorless organic liquids with an ester like odor. Dimethyl malonate is sparingly soluble in water (1 g/50 mL), but miscible in all portions with diethyl ether and ethanol. At room temperature, malonates and alcoholic solutions thereof exist almost exclusively in the keto form. Dimethyl malonates are widely used for the production of vitamins, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, fragrances, and dyes. In the agrochemical field, malonates are mainly used for the production of two classes of herbicides: the cyclohexanedione-type and the sulfonylurea herbicides. The synthesis of the 1,3-cyclohexanedione herbicides commences with a Michael addition of malonates to 1-substituted but-1-en-3-ones followed by ring closure and subsequent decarboxylation.;Malonates are produced either by cobalt-catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetates with carbon monoxide in the presence of alcohol or by hydrolysis of cyanoacetic acid followed by esterification with the respective alcohol, i.e., the carbon monoxide and hydrogen cyanide processs, repsectively. For this dataset the production of dimethyl malonate by means of the hydrogen cyanide process is considered.;Reactions:;Cl-CH2-COONa + NaCN → NC-CH-COONa + NaCl;NC-CH-COONa + 2CH4O + HCl → C5H8O4 + NH3 + NaCl;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated  based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. At the same time, the energy consumption is based on data from literature sources.  Finally, the auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources.   For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;References:;Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Heck T., Hellweg S., Hischier R., Nemecek T., Rebitzer G. and Spielmann M. (2007) Overview and Methodology. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 No. 1. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.org.;Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle as-sessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78, no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003;Harald Strittmatter, Stefan Hildbrand, Peter Pollak: Malonic Acid and Derivatives. Published online: 2007. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: DOI: 10.1002/14356007.a16_063.pub2

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

The activity ends with dimethyl malonate being ready for further transformation or transportation at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2022, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 2003) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled at the Global level. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields.  Furthermore, the source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure. ;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The production of dimethyl malonate is based on hydrogen cyanide and chloroacetic acid, where the intermediate cyanoacetic acid is simultaneously saponified and esterified in the presence of a large excess of mineral acid and alcohol.;Reactions:;Cl-CH2-COONa + NaCN → NC-CH-COONa + NaCl;NC-CH-COONa + 2CH4O + HCl → C5H8O4 + NH3 + NaCl;A solution of sodium cyanide (ca. 25 %) in water is heated to 65 – 70 °C in a stainless steel reaction vessel. An aqueous solution of sodium chloroacetate is then added slowly with stirring; the temperature must not exceed 90 °C. Stirring is maintained at this temperature for an hour. Particular care must be taken to ensure that the hydrogen cyanide, which is formed continuously in small amounts, is trapped and neutralized. The solution of sodium cyanoacetate is concentrated by evaporation under vacuum and then transferred to a glass-lined reaction vessel for hydrolysis of the cyano group and esterification. The alcohol and mineral acid (weight ratio 1:2 to 1:3) are introduced in such a manner that the temperature does not rise above 60 – 80 °C. For each mol of ester, ca. 1.2 mol of alcohol is added. Hydrochloric acid, which is formed as byproduct from unreacted chloroacetic acid, is fed into an absorption column. After the addition of acid and alcohol is complete, the mixture is heated at reflux for 6 – 8 h, whereby the intermediate malonic acid ester monoamide is hydrolyzed to a dialkyl malonate. The pure ester is obtained from the mixture of crude esters by extraction with benzene, toluene, or xylene. The organic phase is washed with dilute sodium hydroxide to remove small amounts of the monoester. The diester is then separated from solvent by distillation at atmospheric pressure, and the malonic ester obtained by distillation under vacuum as a colourless liquid with a minimum assay of 99 % (gas chromatography). The aqueous phase contains considerable amounts of mineral acid and salts and must be treated before being fed to the waste treatment plant. The process is suitable for both the dimethyl and diethyl esters.;Although a relatively simple plant is sufficient for the reaction itself, a sizeable investment is required for treatment of the wastewater and exhaust gas.;The yield based on sodium chloroacetate is 75 – 85 %. Various low molecular mass hydrocarbons, some of them partially chlorinated, are formed as byproducts. In this dataset, an overal yield of 85% was assumed (i.e., an average 92% yield for each reaction step). ;References:;Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Heck T., Hellweg S., Hischier R., Nemecek T., Rebitzer G. and Spielmann M. (2007) Overview and Methodology. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 No. 1. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.org.;Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle as-sessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78, no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003;Harald Strittmatter, Stefan Hildbrand, Peter Pollak: Malonic Acid and Derivatives. Published online: 2007. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: DOI: 10.1002/14356007.a16_063.pub2
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system.
The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 2003) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges.

References:
Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.

exchanges.description: As there was no data available for the production of dimethyl malonate, the values for the consumption of the raw materials are calculated with an assumed yield of 95 % per step (Frischknecht et al. 2007). Hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide are calculated with a yield of 95% if they are used as raw material, and with a yield of 100% if they are used for neutralization of remaining acid or base. The remaining sodium hydroxide from the first step is considered to be neutralized with hydrogen chloride. In the second step the remaining hydrochloric acid is neutralized with sodium hydroxide.

In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of methanol in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

Value reported by Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.

References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Estimation from neutralization steps.

Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Value reported by Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Calculated value based on stoichiometric calculations and literature data. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.

Value reported by Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005. Please note that Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash reported the potential energy recovery of 0.67 MJ per kg of dimethyl malnate produced.

defaultProvider.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of methanol in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of well water in the years 2015-2019 was 18607480 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of well water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 45% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of well water, as that is the share of well water versus river water. This equals 0.00081652 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

As there was no data available for the production of dimethyl malonate, the values for the consumption of the raw materials are calculated with an assumed yield of 95 % per step (Frischknecht et al. 2007).

This equals 0.00096543 m3/kg chemical produced.
